content:
Imagine you are a robot browsing the web, just like humans. Now you need to complete a task. In each iteration, you will receive an Accessibility Tree with numerical label representing information about the page, then follow the guidelines and choose one of the following actions:
1. Click a Web Element.
2. Delete existing content in a textbox and then type content. 
3. Scroll up or down. Multiple scrolls are allowed to browse the webpage. Pay attention!! The default scroll is the whole window. If the scroll widget is located in a certain area of the webpage, then you have to specify a Web Element in that area. I would hover the mouse there and then scroll.
4. Wait. Typically used to wait for unfinished webpage processes, with a duration of 5 seconds.
5. Go back, returning to the previous webpage.
6. Google, directly jump to the Google search page. When you can't find information in some websites, try starting over with Google.
7. Answer. This action should only be chosen when all questions in the task have been solved.

Correspondingly, Action should STRICTLY follow the format:
- Click [Numerical_Label]
- Type [Numerical_Label]; [Content]
- Scroll [Numerical_Label or WINDOW]; [up or down]
- Wait
- GoBack
- Google
- ANSWER; [content]

Key Guidelines You MUST follow:
* Action guidelines *
1) To input text, NO need to click textbox first, directly type content. After typing, the system automatically hits `ENTER` key. Sometimes you should click the search button to apply search filters. Try to use simple language when searching.  
2) You must Distinguish between textbox and search button, don't type content into the button! If no textbox is found, you may need to click the search button first before the textbox is displayed. 
3) Execute only one action per iteration. 
4) STRICTLY Avoid repeating the same action if the webpage remains unchanged. You may have selected the wrong web element or numerical label. Continuous use of the Wait is also NOT allowed.
5) When a complex Task involves multiple questions or steps, select "ANSWER" only at the very end, after addressing all of these questions (steps). Flexibly combine your own abilities with the information in the web page. Double check the formatting requirements in the task when ANSWER. 
* Web Browsing Guidelines *
1) Don't interact with useless web elements like Login, Sign-in, donation that appear in Webpages. Pay attention to Key Web Elements like search textbox and menu.
2) Vsit video websites like YouTube is allowed BUT you can't play videos. Clicking to download PDF is allowed and will be analyzed by the Assistant API.
3) Focus on the date in task, you must look for results that match the date. It may be necessary to find the correct year, month and day at calendar.
4) Pay attention to the filter and sort functions on the page, which, combined with scroll, can help you solve conditions like 'highest', 'cheapest', 'lowest', 'earliest', etc. Try your best to find the answer that best fits the task.

Your reply should strictly follow the format:
Thought: {Your brief thoughts (briefly summarize the info that will help ANSWER)}
Action: {One Action format you choose}

Then the User will provide:
Observation: {Accessibility Tree of a web page}

Now given a task: Browse the ESPN+ page from ESPN for a brief summary of what ESPN+ Tools is used for.  Please interact with https://www.espn.com/ and get the answer.Observation: An accessibility tree. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: Need to search ESPN site for "ESPN+ Tools" description. Use the Search textbox (#5) to search.
Action: Type [5]; ESPN+ Tools

The action you have chosen cannot be exected. Please double-check if you have selected the wrong Numerical Label or Action or Action format. Then provide the revised Thought and Action.Observation: An accessibility tree. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: Probably need to open the search interface by clicking the search icon before typing our query.
Action: Click [4326]
Observation: An accessibility tree. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: Search box is focused; we can type our query to find info about ESPN+ Tools.
Action: Type [5]; ESPN+ Tools
Observation: An accessibility tree. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: Need to see more search results further down.
Action: Scroll WINDOW; down
Observation: An accessibility tree. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: It looks like the ESPN site search doesn‚Äôt surface a page called ‚ÄúESPN+¬†Tools.‚Äù The task is to reach the ESPN+ landing page and find a short description of what ESPN+¬†Tools is for. The quickest way is to Google the exact term and then go to the official ESPN page that appears.
Action: Google
Observation: An accessibility tree. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: Enter Google search for ‚ÄúESPN+ Tools‚Äù to locate ESPN page describing it.
Action: Type [1]; ESPN+ Tools
Observation: An accessibility tree. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: Google blocked us with CAPTCHA, so we‚Äôll return to ESPN and navigate via its own menus to find the ESPN+ product landing page, which should include a blurb about ‚ÄúESPN+ Tools.‚Äù
Action: Click [11385]

The action you have chosen cannot be exected. Please double-check if you have selected the wrong Numerical Label or Action or Action format. Then provide the revised Thought and Action.Observation: An accessibility tree. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: Google search is blocked; return to previous page.
Action: GoBack
Observation: An accessibility tree. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: Use Google search bar to query ‚ÄúESPN+ Tools site:espn.com‚Äù to find ESPN page describing it.
Action: Type [1]; ESPN+ Tools site:espn.com
Observation: An accessibility tree. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: We‚Äôve hit Google‚Äôs CAPTCHA, so let‚Äôs abandon Google. Return to the ESPN site we came from and continue searching there.
Action: GoBack
Observation: An accessibility tree. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: To continue searching on ESPN‚Äôs own site, return to the ESPN webpage we started with (the Google detour is unnecessary and blocked).  
Action: GoBack
Observation: An accessibility tree. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: Need more targeted results. The ‚ÄúTop Results‚Äù tab might surface an ESPN+ Tools landing page if it exists.  
Action: Click [3017]
Observation: An accessibility tree. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: The hamburger ‚ÄúMenu‚Äù button (11) in the global navigation should let me open ESPN‚Äôs main menu, where I can pick ESPN+ and then look for a section called ‚ÄúTools‚Äù or ‚ÄúESPN+ Tools.‚Äù  
Action: Click [11]
Observation: An accessibility tree. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: Within the opened hamburger menu, there‚Äôs a dedicated ‚ÄúESPN+‚Äù button (label 4914). Opening it should bring me to the ESPN+ landing section, where I can look for a subsection or blurb called ‚ÄúTools.‚Äù  
Action: Click [4914]
Observation: An accessibility tree. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: In the ESPN+ submenu, there is a ‚ÄúSupport & FAQs‚Äù link (5508). Opening that section should give product‚Äërelated help pages, likely where ‚ÄúESPN+¬†Tools‚Äù is described.  
Action: Click [5508]
Observation: An accessibility tree. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: Use the FAQs page‚Äôs search field to look up ‚ÄúESPN+¬†Tools‚Äù directly.  
Action: Type [5579]; ESPN+ Tools
Observation: An accessibility tree. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: Results list doesn‚Äôt show a page about ‚ÄúESPN+¬†Tools.‚Äù A better path is to open the ESPN+ marketing site (plus.espn.com) via ‚ÄúDon‚Äôt Have¬†ESPN+?‚Äù; such landing pages usually list the features‚Äîincluding the Tools section‚Äîand give a short description.
Action: Click [4895]

The action you have chosen cannot be exected. Please double-check if you have selected the wrong Numerical Label or Action or Action format. Then provide the revised Thought and Action.Observation: An accessibility tree. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: We‚Äôre on the support search results, and nothing references ‚ÄúESPN+¬†Tools.‚Äù¬†Likely it‚Äôs described on the ESPN+ marketing/landing page (plus.espn.com). The quickest step is to leave Support and go back to the ESPN+ submenu in the main ESPN site so we can open the actual ESPN+ page.  
Action: GoBack
Observation: An accessibility tree. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: We need to leave Support and return to ESPN.com, then open the ESPN+ marketing page (where ESPN+ Tools is described). The footer has an ‚ÄúESPN‚Äù link that takes us back to the main site.  
Action: Click [6301]

The action you have chosen cannot be exected. Please double-check if you have selected the wrong Numerical Label or Action or Action format. Then provide the revised Thought and Action.Observation: An accessibility tree. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: There‚Äôs an autocomplete suggestion ‚ÄúESPN+¬†Tools‚Äù (6536) in the search dropdown; selecting it should open the related support article that explains what ESPN+ Tools is for.  
Action: Click [6536]
Observation: An accessibility tree. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: There‚Äôs an ‚ÄúESPN‚Äù link in the footer (6301) that should take me back to the main ESPN site; from there I can open the ESPN+ marketing page to locate the ESPN+¬†Tools description.
Action: Click [6301]

The action you have chosen cannot be exected. Please double-check if you have selected the wrong Numerical Label or Action or Action format. Then provide the revised Thought and Action.Observation: An accessibility tree. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: Let‚Äôs see if the Support search results actually contain an article titled ‚ÄúESPN+¬†Tools‚Äù; scrolling below the FAQ category list may reveal it.
Action: Scroll WINDOW; down
Observation: An accessibility tree. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: Need to return to the top of the FAQ page (search box area) so I can re‚Äëselect the ‚ÄúESPN+¬†Tools‚Äù autocomplete suggestion and open the article.
Action: Scroll WINDOW; up
Observation: An accessibility tree. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: The autocomplete suggestion ‚ÄúESPN+¬†Tools‚Äù (6536) is visible under the search box‚Äîselecting it should open the support article that explains what ESPN+ Tools is used for.
Action: Click [6536]
Observation: An accessibility tree. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: The ‚ÄúESPN‚Äù link near the bottom (6301) will take us back to the main ESPN.com site; from there we can open the ESPN+ marketing page that contains the description of ESPN+¬†Tools.
Action: Click [6301]

The action you have chosen cannot be exected. Please double-check if you have selected the wrong Numerical Label or Action or Action format. Then provide the revised Thought and Action.Observation: An accessibility tree. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: The ‚ÄúESPN‚Äù footer link (6301) should take us back to ESPN.com where the ESPN+ marketing page is accessible. Let‚Äôs click it to leave Support.
Action: Click [6301]

The action you have chosen cannot be exected. Please double-check if you have selected the wrong Numerical Label or Action or Action format. Then provide the revised Thought and Action.Observation: An accessibility tree. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: Clicking the ESPN logo at the top of the Support page (element¬†5556) should navigate back to the main ESPN site, where we can reach the ESPN+ marketing page that describes ESPN+¬†Tools.
Action: Click [5556]

Observation: please analyze the accessibility tree and give the Thought and Action.
